body:
Please fill out the form completely. 

Latest versions of the GUIs all auto jump to last labeled frame. 

Sounds like you have the wrong version of matplotlib

Your Operating system and DeepLabCut version :
Windows 10 64 bit, 
Anaconda env for GPU, deeplabcut version 2.0.7.1
Browser: Chrome

I am attaching below my environment dependencies. matplotlib version is 3.03.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45516669/63275403-601fea80-c299-11e9-9dc5-7fd7dc6a022b.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/45516669/63275430-6dd57000-c299-11e9-9ba9-098f388e3ba0.png)
what version of wxpython do you have installed? I don't see it in your env list.
closing due to inactivity, but please update us if you can (my guess is you need to re-install wxPython)

Hi,
Sorry for replying late- I was out of the lab for a couple of days.

The current version of wxPython I have is 4.0.6 msw (phoenix) wxWidgets 3.0.5

Thank you for your help!
All the best,
Maya

Hello, did anyone solve this? I am experiencing the same problem when processing images in a long stack.
Since it seemed related to the toolbar, I have disabled it with `mpl.rcParams['toolbar'] = 'None'`.

Then, a somewhat similar error occurs:
wxAssertionError: C++ assertion "m_hdc" failed at ..\..\src\msw\textmeasure.cpp(64) in wxTextMeasure::BeginMeasuring(): Must not be used with non-native wxDCs

Caused by:
    fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\pyplot.py", line 1209, in subplots
    fig = figure(**fig_kw)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\pyplot.py", line 545, in figure
    **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1969, in new_figure_manager
    return super().new_figure_manager(num, *args, **kwargs)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backend_bases.py", line 3252, in new_figure_manager
    return cls.new_figure_manager_given_figure(num, fig)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1973, in new_figure_manager_given_figure
    frame = cls._frame_class(num, figure)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1101, in __init__
    self.statusbar = StatusBarWx(self)
  File "C:\Users\...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1585, in __init__
    self.SetFieldsCount(2)

Could it be related to multi-threads? (like in the answer to [this question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/22211658/implementing-my-own-event-loop-in-a-wxpython-application)?)

With `plt.ioff()`, I sure am openning, saving and closing figures in a new window inside a `for`, while updating a gauge in the main interface, therefore, I have tried using wxCallAfter and even commenting the gauge update, but I still get the same error. Any suggestions are welcome :)

How many images are you processing per folder? (Keep in mind you can delete all/most frames that do not contain the behavior before labeling).

________________________________
From: Marcelo Zoccoler <notifications@github.com>
Sent: Tuesday, November 26, 2019 8:35:29 AM
To: AlexEMG/DeepLabCut <DeepLabCut@noreply.github.com>
Cc: Subscribed <subscribed@noreply.github.com>
Subject: Re: [AlexEMG/DeepLabCut] problem with using labeling GUI (#400)


Hello, did anyone solve this? I am experiencing the same problem when processing images in a long stack.
Since it seemed related to the toolbar, I have disabled it with mpl.rcParams['toolbar'] = 'None'.

Then, a somewhat similar error occurs:
wxAssertionError: C++ assertion "m_hdc" failed at ....\src\msw\textmeasure.cpp(64) in wxTextMeasure::BeginMeasuring(): Must not be used with non-native wxDCs

Caused by:
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))
File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\pyplot.py", line 1209, in subplots

File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\pyplot.py", line 545, in figure
**kwargs)

return super().new_figure_manager(num, *args, **kwargs)
File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backend_bases.py", line 3252, in new_figure_manager
return cls.new_figure_manager_given_figure(num, fig)
File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1973, in new_figure_manager_given_figure

File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1101, in init

File "C:\Users...\lib\site-packages\matplotlib\backends\backend_wx.py", line 1585, in init
self.SetFieldsCount(2)

Could it be related to multi-threads? (like in the answer to this question<https://urldefense.proofpoint.com/v2/url?u=https-3A__stackoverflow.com_questions_22211658_implementing-2Dmy-2Down-2Devent-2Dloop-2Din-2Da-2Dwxpython-2Dapplication&d=DwMCaQ&c=WO-RGvefibhHBZq3fL85hQ&r=11wEEDBv3Ke3n3b8dICjuQC5vgZ23dfGPax018VOZ2g&m=040G7Q2m8yoazJ1CcBOasiFyn_fjsxF7tNdWAWGRqfs&s=PTM03m9ATUAJZ0R6gjLozlgApuil_TC0_8QyDO8dmDs&e=>?)

With plt.ioff(), I sure am openning, saving and closing figures in a new window inside a for, while updating a gauge in the main interface, therefore, I have tried using wxCallAfter and even commenting the gauge update, but I still get the same error. Any suggestions are welcome :)

Oh, first of all I apologize because now I realized that I was not using your DeepLabCut toolbox, it just happened that I found this thread because it was the only result I got where someone had the same problem I am having. Therefore you may disconsider this if you wish.

In any case, if you believe it is a problem you may run into as well, I'll leave my answer below.

I am processing one stack of images (nframes x 100 x 100) in a loop, dealing with one frame per iteraction. The error started popping up around frame 1240 with a stack of nframes = 1500.

Let me provide shorter version where the error also occurs (this function is executed once user clicks a button in main interface):

    def OnRUN(self,event):    
        plt.ioff()    
        for fr in range(nframes):    
            label_image = measure.label(self.video_bin[fr], background=0)    
            image_label_overlay = label2rgb(label_image, image=self.video_bin[fr])    
            fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(10, 6))    
            ax.imshow(image_label_overlay)    
            plt.axis('off')    
            imname = 'imgout'+str(fr)+'.tif'    
            impath = os.path.join(self.dirname,'Output',imname)    
            plt.savefig(impath,bbox_inches='tight',facecolor='black',edgecolor='none')    
            plt.close(fig)    
        plt.ion()

Hello, 

I also recently encountered this problem while refining labels on 78 images (based on the labels from the algorithm). I was able to adjust labels on 72 frames before I encountered this issue.

Any help would be much appreciated. Thank you!
seems to be an issue with labelling a large volume of frames from a single video, i consistently encounter it at ~700 frames in.

In case it helps, I've created [this related question](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/59092214/matplotlib-wxpython-backend-crashing-after-large-image-stack-processing) on stackoverflow with a small example to test this situation. If a solution comes up, we may all benefit from it.

Hello, I am having the exact same problem Maya experienced. Has there been any update on the solution? I am labeling a large volume of frames as well. I have also updated my wxPython and matplotlib to the latest versions but this hasnt helped.

Also is there away to go straight to the last labeled image instead of having to go through from the beginning?

The labeling GUI is not designed to be used this way, i.e. the goal of this project was to show that small amounts of data (taken from different videos) would be labeled, Thus, a typical use case is labeling 20-50 frames per folder (that are from different videos to cover the whole behavioral space). 

The latest matplotlib is not suggested either, btw. 

Also, when you open the GUI is DOES automatically jump to the last labeled frame, assuming you have saved your annotations. This was an update nearly a year ago, so be sure you are using something newer than 2.0.6 (i.e. latest is 2.1.5.2)
